questions.text: A patient with loss of sensation on lateral 3 1 / 2 hand and thenar atrophy. Which nerve is involved?
questions.explanation:
Nerve

Motor Dysfunction

Sensory Dysfunction

Common Deformity/Condition

Median Nerve

Weakness of thenar muscles (thumb opposition), flexor muscles of forearm

Loss of sensation in lateral 3.5 fingers (thumb, index, middle, half of the ring finger)

Ape hand (thenar atrophy), Carpal tunnel syndrome

Ulnar Nerve (Option B ruled out)

Weakness of intrinsic hand muscles (especially interossei), hypothenar muscles

Loss of sensation in medial 1.5 fingers (little and half of the ring finger)

Claw hand, Hypothenar atrophy, Cubital tunnel syndrome

Radial Nerve (Option C ruled out)

Inability to extend wrist and fingers (wrist drop)

Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the hand

Wrist drop, Saturday night palsy, Radial tunnel syndrome

Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN) (Option D ruled out)

Inability to flex thumb and index finger (loss of flexion of distal phalanges)

No sensory loss (pure motor neuropathy)

Inability to make "OK" sign (difficulty flexing thumb and index finger)

Long Thoracic Nerve

Weakness of serratus anterior muscle, affecting scapular movement

No sensory loss

Winged scapula (scapula protrudes from the back)

questions.text: A physician is evaluating a patient for an occupational disease and finds that a coproporphyrin test has been performed. Which of the following conditions is most likely suspected?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A

Diagnostic Test Urine coproporphyrin levels
Pathophysiology Lead inhibits heme synthesis, causing accumulation of porphyrins
Symptoms Neurological symptoms, abdominal pain, anemia, peripheral neuropathy
Other Diagnostic Methods Blood lead levels, X-ray fluorescence analysis
Management Chelation therapy (e.g., EDTA, DMSA)

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with acute epigastric pain and elevated serum lipase. He was stabilized after three days. What is the most common pathology associated with the chest X-ray obtained?

Condition Primary Event Lung Complication Time of Onset Imaging Finding
Acute pancreatitis Inflammation, enzyme release ARDS Within 24–72 hours Bilateral infiltrates (non-cardiogenic)
Heart failure Volume overload Pulmonary edema Variable Bilateral perihilar haziness + cardiomegaly
Pulmonary embolism Thrombus in pulmonary arteries Infarcts, pleural-based opacities Sudden onset Wedge-shaped infarcts on CXR/CT
Miliary TB Disseminated TB infection Miliary nodules throughout lung Subacute/chronic Uniform millet-sized nodules

questions.text: When do you put a victim in the following position?

options.label: A
options.text: Conscious patient with pulse & breathing present.

options.label: B
options.text: Unconscious patient with pulse & breathing present.

options.label: C
options.text: Unconscious patient with pulse present but no breathing.

options.label: D
options.text: Unconscious patient without pulse but breathing present.

questions.correct_answer: B. Unconscious patient with pulse & breathing present.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Unconscious patient with pulse and breathing present

Patient Status Recovery Position Used? Reason
Conscious with pulse & breathing (Option A) No No need to alter position unless needed for comfort or other reasons.
Unconscious with pulse & breathing (Option B) Yes Prevents airway obstruction and aspiration.
Unconscious with pulse but no breathing (Option C) No Requires rescue breathing or CPR, not recovery position.
Unconscious without pulse but breathing (Option D) No This is physiologically unlikely; no pulse = no circulation.

questions.text: A female presented with 1x 1 cm thyroid swelling. What is next best step in management?

questions.text: Calculate the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for the year 2023, given the following events: Total women who died: 6 Total live births: 4000 Causes of death: 1 due to road traffic accident (RTA) 1 due to sepsis 1 due to obstructed labor 1 due to eclampsia 1 due to ectopic pregnancy 1 due to snake bite
questions.explanation: Correct Option C

questions.text: A patient has pleural fluid with an LDH level greater than 0.6 times the serum LDH and protein greater than 0.5 times the serum protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Tuberculosis (TB)

Condition

Tuberculosis (TB)

Key Clinical Features

Exudative pleural effusion with high protein and LDH levels

Diagnostic Criteria

Light's criteria: Pleural fluid protein > 0.5 times serum protein, LDH > 0.6 times serum LDH

Differential Diagnosis

Excludes heart failure, hepatic failure, and renal failure due to their association with transudative effusions

Rationale

TB is a common cause of exudative effusion, fitting the pleural fluid analysis described

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding von Willebrand disease is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Type 2 von Willebrand disease is associated with a moderate bleeding tendency

options.label: B
options.text: Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a complete absence of factor VIII

options.label: C
options.text: Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood

options.label: D
options.text: Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes subtypes with varying defects in von Willebrand factor.

questions.correct_answer: C. Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childh

Type 1 von Willebrand Disease

Mild bleeding tendency; partial deficiency of von Willebrand factor

Type 2 von Willebrand Disease

Moderate bleeding tendency; includes subtypes with varying defects in von Willebrand factor

Type 3 von Willebrand Disease

Severe bleeding tendency; severe deficiency or absence of von Willebrand factor, leading to very low factor VIII levels

questions.text: What is the typical pressure setting for the valve in a Mapleson circuit?
questions.explanation:
Feature Details
Used in Anesthesia, manual or controlled ventilation
APL Valve Purpose Limits peak airway pressure by releasing excess gas
Valve Pressure Setting Typically 30–40 cm H₂O, especially during controlled ventilation
Spontaneous Ventilation Use Valve kept open to atmosphere (minimal resistance)
Risk if too high >40 cm H₂O may cause barotrauma
Units Used cm H₂O (not mm Hg) in respiratory and anesthesia circuits

questions.text: A patient with a history of hypertension presents with atrial fibrillation, shortness of breath and Bilateral basal crackles on auscultation. Least important in management would be:

options.label: A
options.text: Start on anticoagulants like warf or Doac

options.label: C
options.text: Cardioversion to correct rhythm if hemodynamically remain unstable even after medical management

questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Start beta block

Condition

Atrial Fibrillation with Shortness of Breath

Least Important

Start Beta Blocker

Reason

In acute settings with symptoms of heart failure and hemodynamic instability, immediate rate control and rhythm stabilization might take priority. Beta blockers, while important, may not be the immediate choice in such scenarios compared to other options like anticoagulants, cardioversion, or IV digoxin.

questions.text: Aprepitant, a drug used to prevent late-onset chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, acts through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - NK-1 Antag

questions.text: A patient presents with acute epigastric pain and an increase in serum lipase levels. Three days after stabilization, a chest X-ray is obtained. What is the most common pathology behind the chest X-ray findings?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Non-cardiogenic pulmonary

Condition

Acute Pancreatitis with Non-cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema

Key Clinical Features

Acute epigastric pain, elevated serum lipase, systemic inflammation

Common Chest X-ray Findings

Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema (due to increased capillary permeability)

Differential Diagnosis

Differentiated from cardiogenic pulmonary edema (increased PCWP), pulmonary embolism (more sudden respiratory compromise), and aspiration pneumonitis (associated with a history of aspiration)

Rationale

The systemic inflammatory response in acute pancreatitis can lead to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, a common complication in severe cases

questions.text: A patient presents with redness, extreme eye pain, and diminished vision. The patient frequently wears contact lenses. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C – Acanth

questions.text: An elderly woman reports difficulty in buttoning her shirt and increased clumsiness during daily activities. On examination, she is unable to make an 'O' shape by opposing her thumb and index finger. Which of the following muscles is most likely involved?
questions.explanation:
Muscle Group

Muscles

Function

Innervation

Thenar muscles

• Abductor pollicis brevis

• Flexor pollicis brevis

• Opponens pollicis

• Abducts thumb

 

• Flexes thumb

• Opposes thumb

AbPB: Median nerve (recurrent branch)

FPB: Dual (Median + Ulnar)

OP: Median (variable)

Hypothenar muscles

• Abductor digiti minimi

• Flexor digiti minimi brevis

• Opponens digiti minimi

Controls movement of little finger

Ulnar nerve (deep branch)

Lumbricals

• 1st & 2nd (lateral)

• 3rd & 4th (medial)

Flex MCPs and extend IP joints

Lateral 2: Median nerve

Medial 2: Ulnar nerve

Palmar interossei

• Three muscles (unipennate)

Adduction of fingers (PAD)

Ulnar nerve (deep branch)

Dorsal interossei

• Four muscles (bipennate)

Abduction of fingers (DAB)

Ulnar nerve (deep branch)

Adductor pollicis

• Oblique and transverse heads

Adducts the thumb

Ulnar nerve (deep branch)

Palmaris brevis

• One small superficial muscle

Tenses skin over hypothenar eminence

Ulnar nerve (superficial branch)

questions.text: Implantation occurs on which day post fertilization?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Day (Post-Fertilization)

Key Event

Fertilization

Day 0

Sperm fertilizes oocyte in ampulla of fallopian tube

Zygote Formation

Day 1

Single-cell zygote undergoes cleavage

Morula Formation

Day 3-4

16-cell stage compacted into a solid ball

Blastocyst Formation

Day 5

Fluid-filled cavity forms; blastocyst reaches the uterus

Implantation Begins

Day 5-6

Blastocyst attaches to the endometrium

Trophoblast Invasion

Day 6-8

Syncytiotrophoblast formation, hCG secretion begins

Complete Implantation

Day 9-10

Blastocyst is fully embedded in the endometrial lining

questions.text: A child presents with deformities, normal serum calcium, normal PTH, low phosphate, and elevated ALP. Which is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Vitamin D Dependent Rickets Type 1 (VDDR type 1)

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin D Dependent Rickets Type 2 (VDDR type 2)

questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Hypophosphatemic rick

Calcipenic rickets/Nutritional rickets  Phosphoenic rickets/renal rickets
  • Cause: Deficiency of calcium due to defective absorption absorption and improper supply of calcium.
  • Low calcium levels are present.
  •  It is due to low phosphate levels.
  • It is caused by excessive excretion in the kidney.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital following a road traffic accident (RTA). He presents with confusion, irritability, and tremors. The patient has a history of daily alcohol consumption. Which drug is most appropriate to prevent withdrawal symptoms in this patient?

questions.text: What is the confirmatory test for the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - NMR S

Condition Differentiation between Tuberculoma and Neurocysticercosis in cases of ring-enhancing brain lesions.
Key Diagnostic Modality NMR Spectroscopy
Associated Imaging Findings Ring-enhancing lesions on MRI, which may be indicative of either tuberculoma or neurocysticercosis.
Rationale for Diagnosis NMR Spectroscopy provides detailed biochemical and chemical information about lesions, helping differentiate between tuberculoma and neurocysticercosis.
Differential Diagnosis Use of NMR Spectroscopy to differentiate between tuberculoma (caused by TB) and neurocysticercosis (caused by Taenia solium).
Importance of Confirmation Accurate differentiation between these conditions is crucial for appropriate treatment decisions (antitubercular therapy vs. antiparasitic therapy).

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD by his parents with complaints of recurrent infections. On mediastinal imaging, the thymus gland was found to be absent. Based on further investigation, ADA levels are low. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Severe combined immu

XLR ( X-linked recessive variety)

 

AR ( Autosomal recessive variety)
  • Most common
  • Defect in the gamma subunit of cytokine receptors: IL2, IL4, IL7, Il15.
  • IL 2 and IL 15: Defective NK cells
  • IL 4: No antibody production
  • IL 7: Defective T-cell development
  • B cells function normally.

There are three types of AR :

  • Adenosine deaminase deficiency (most common): Involves all cells (B cells, T cells, and NK cells)
  • JAK-3 defects: It affects cytokine development. Defective T cells and NK cells. B cells function normally.
  • RAG1 and RAG2 (Recombinant activation gene) defect: This gene is needed to develop B cell and T cell receptors. When this gene is affected, defects in B cells and T cells are observed. NK cells function normally.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient with a 10-day history of binge drinking presents with altered sensorium, slurred speech, and unconsciousness, with a blood glucose level of 49 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Intravenous thiamine infusion followed by dextrose

options.label: B
options.text: Intravenous vitamin K followed by dextrose

questions.correct_answer: A. Intravenous thiamine infusion followed by dextrose
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Intravenous thiamine infusion

Condition

Alcoholic hypoglycemia with risk of Wernicke's encephalopathy

Immediate Concern

Preventing Wernicke's encephalopathy

Required Treatment

Intravenous thiamine infusion

Subsequent Treatment

Dextrose infusion to correct hypoglycemia

Rationale

Thiamine deficiency in alcoholism can lead to neurological damage if glucose is given without thiamine.

questions.text: Identify the amputation shown in the image below.
questions.explanation:
Type of Amputation

Description

Indications

Functionality and Prosthesis Considerations

Partial Foot Amputation

Involves the removal of part of the foot, including toes or part of the forefoot.
  • Severe trauma
  • Diabetes-related complications (e.g., gangrene)
  • Infection
  • Retains some function of the foot for walking
  • Custom prostheses for toes and forefoot

Transmetatarsal Amputation (TMA)

Amputation through the metatarsal bones, removing the forefoot but leaving the midfoot and hindfoot intact.
  • Severe foot injury
  • Diabetes-related complications
  • Gangrene or infection
  • Often requires a prosthesis that fits the residual part of the foot for better weight-bearing

Lisfranc Amputation

Removal of the forefoot, including the toes and metatarsal bones, but preserving the hindfoot and ankle.
  • Severe trauma
  • Chronic infection
  • Vascular disease
  • Prosthetic options are complex due to the loss of the midfoot
  • Often uses a custom device

Syme’s Amputation (Option D)

Removal of the foot at the ankle joint, with the heel pad being preserved.
  • Trauma
  • Severe infections
  • Vascular disease (e.g., gangrene)
  • Functional prosthesis can be used, providing near-normal walking function
  • Heel pad aids in load-bearing

Transtibial Amputation (Below-Knee)

Amputation below the knee joint, typically through the tibia and fibula.
  • Severe trauma
  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Diabetes complications
  • Tumors
  • Functional prostheses (below-knee prosthesis) with ankle and foot components
  • Retains knee function

Knee Disarticulation

Amputation through the knee joint, preserving the femur while removing the tibia and fibula.
  • Severe trauma
  • Infection
  • Vascular disease
  • Bone cancer
  • Prosthetic knee and foot required
  • Retains better residual limb length for prosthesis fitting

Transfemoral Amputation (Above-Knee) (Option A)

Amputation above the knee joint, through the femur.
  • Severe trauma
  • Cancer
  • Chronic infection
  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Requires a prosthesis with both knee and ankle components
  • More energy is required for walking

Hip Disarticulation

Removal of the entire leg at the hip joint, including the femur.
  • Severe trauma
  • Tumors
  • Vascular disease
  • Severe infection
  • Prosthetic limb involves the hip joint, requires specialized sockets and joints for movement

questions.text: A man presented with bilateral swelling of his legs, diarrhoea, and dyspnea. He has a history of consuming mustard oil from a local vendor. Which test should be performed by the health inspector to check for the adulterant?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features

Bilateral leg swelling, diarrhoea, dyspnoea, features of glaucoma and heart failure even up to death.

Causative agent

Sanguinarine (toxic alkaloid present in argemone oil).

Detection of contamination
  • Nitric acid test: the presence of a red-brown ring when added to the sample oil indicates the presence of argemone oil.
  • Paper chromatography test. Most sensitive and better than nitric acid test (Option A) (Option B ruled out)

Prevention
  • Accidental contamination: removing argemone weeds growing among oilseed crops.
  • Deliberate contamination: enforcing Prevention of Food Adulteration Act.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely based on the lab values given? Blood pH: 7.3 (indicating mild acidosis) Sodium (Na+): 134 mEq/L (mildly decreased) Potassium (K+): 2.8 mEq/L (hypokalemia) Chloride (Cl-): 113 mEq/L (elevated) Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻): 12 mEq/L (low, indicating metabolic acidosis) Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN): 3 mg/dL (low-normal) Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL (normal) Urinary pH: 9.4 (alkaline)
questions.correct_answer: A. Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) Type 1 (Distal RTA)
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - RTA Type 1 (Distal RTA)

questions.text: An infant presents with recurrent chest infections and tachypnea. Identify the likely clinical condition.
questions.explanation: Correct Option A

questions.text: What is the expected finding in a patient with the following CXR?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Paradoxical breathing

Condition

Flail Chest

Key Clinical Features

Multiple rib fractures with a free-floating chest wall segment, leading to paradoxical movement of the chest during respiration

Expected Respiratory Pattern

Paradoxical breathing: inward movement of the chest wall segment during inspiration and outward during expiration

Differential Diagnosis

Differentiated from Kussmaul (metabolic acidosis), Apneustic (brainstem injury), and Bronchial breathing (lung consolidation)

Rationale

Paradoxical breathing is directly linked to the loss of chest wall stability due to rib fractures in flail chest
